The **Queen of Hearts** is a fictional character from the book _[Alice's
Adventures in Wonderland](/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland "Alice's
Adventures in Wonderland")_ by the writer [Lewis Carroll](/wiki/Lewis_Carroll
"Lewis Carroll"), in which she appears as the primary antagonist. She is a
foul-tempered monarch whom Carroll himself describes as "a blind fury", and
who is quick to give death sentences at the slightest offense. One of her most
famous lines she states often is "[Off with their heads](/wiki/Decapitation
"Decapitation")!"

The Queen is referred to as a card from a pack of [playing
cards](/wiki/Playing_card "Playing card") by Alice, yet somehow she is able to
talk and is the ruler of the lands in the story, alongside her tiny husband,
the [King of
Hearts](/wiki/King_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\) "King of
Hearts \(Alice's Adventures in Wonderland\)"). She is often confused with the
[Red Queen](/wiki/Red_Queen_\(Through_the_Looking-Glass\) "Red Queen \(Through
the Looking-Glass\)") from the sequel, _[Through the Looking-
Glass](/wiki/Through_the_Looking-Glass "Through the Looking-Glass")_ ,
although the two are very different.

##
Overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Overview")]

[Alice](/wiki/Alice_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\) "Alice \(Alice's
Adventures in Wonderland\)") observes three playing cards painting white roses
red. They drop to the ground face down at the approach of the Queen of Hearts,
whom Alice has never met. When the Queen arrives and asks Alice who is lying
on the ground (since the backs of all playing cards look alike), Alice tells
her that she does not know. The Queen then becomes frustrated and commands
that her head be severed. She is deterred by her comparatively moderate
husband by being reminded that Alice is only a child.

Generally, however, as we are told by Carroll:

    _The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small. 'Off with his head!' she said, without even looking round._

One of the Queen's hobbies – besides ordering executions – is
[croquet](/wiki/Croquet "Croquet"); however it is Wonderland croquet, where
the balls are live [hedgehogs](/wiki/Hedgehog "Hedgehog") and the mallets are
[flamingoes](/wiki/Flamingo "Flamingo"). This is presumably with the aim that
the birds' blunt beaks should strike, but, as Alice observes, it is
complicated by the fact that they keep looking back up at the players- as well
as the hedgehogs' tendency to scuttle away without waiting to be hit. The
Queen's soldiers act as the arches (or hoops) on the croquet grounds, but have
to leave off being arches every time the Queen has an executioner drag away
the victim, so that, by the end of the game in the story, the only players
that remain are the Queen herself, the King, and Alice.

Despite the frequency of death sentences, it would appear few people are
actually beheaded, [the King of
Hearts](/wiki/King_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\) "King of
Hearts \(Alice's Adventures in Wonderland\)"), quietly pardons many of his
subjects when the Queen is not looking (although this did not seem to be the
case with [The Duchess](/wiki/Duchess_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)
"Duchess \(Alice's Adventures in Wonderland\)")), and her soldiers humor her
but do not carry out her orders. [The
Gryphon](/wiki/Gryphon_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\) "Gryphon
\(Alice's Adventures in Wonderland\)") tells Alice, "It's all her
[fancy](/w/index.php?title=Fancy_\(interest\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fancy
\(interest\) \(page does not exist\)"): she never executes nobody, you know."
Nevertheless, all creatures in Wonderland fear the Queen. In the final
chapters, the Queen sentences Alice again (for defending the [Knave of
Hearts](/wiki/Knave_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\) "Knave of
Hearts \(Alice's Adventures in Wonderland\)")), and she offers a bizarre
approach towards [justice](/wiki/Justice "Justice"): sentence before verdict.

Modern portrayals in popular culture usually let her play the role of a
villain because of the menace the character exemplifies, but in the book she
does not fill that purpose. She is just one of the many obstacles that Alice
has to encounter on the journey, but unlike other obstacles, she makes a
higher potential threat.

##
Origins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Origins")]

The Queen is believed by
some[_[who?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] to be a caricature of [Queen
Victoria](/wiki/Queen_Victoria "Queen Victoria"), with elements of reality
that Dodgson felt correctly would make her at once instantly recognizable to
parents reading the story to children, and also fantastical enough to make her
unrecognizable to children. The reference is explicit in [Jonathan
Miller](/wiki/Jonathan_Miller "Jonathan Miller")'s [1966 television
version](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(1966_TV_play\) "Alice in Wonderland
\(1966 TV play\)") where she and the King of Hearts are portrayed without any
attempt at fantasy, or disguise as to their true natures or personality.

The Queen may also be a reference to [Queen Margaret](/wiki/Margaret_of_Anjou
"Margaret of Anjou") of the [House of Lancaster](/wiki/House_of_Lancaster
"House of Lancaster"). During the [War of the Roses](/wiki/War_of_the_Roses
"War of the Roses"), a red rose was the symbol of the House Lancaster. Their
rivals, the [House of York](/wiki/House_of_York "House of York"), had a white
rose for their symbol. The gardeners' painting the white roses red may be a
reference to these two houses.

##
Illustrations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Illustrations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Elizabeth_de_Mowbray_Duchess_of_Norfolk_2.jpg/200px-
Elizabeth_de_Mowbray_Duchess_of_Norfolk_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Elizabeth_de_Mowbray_Duchess_of_Norfolk_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Elizabeth_de_Mowbray_Duchess_of_Norfolk_2.jpg "Enlarge")

Image of [Elizabeth de Mowbray, Duchess of
Norfolk](/wiki/Elizabeth_de_Mowbray,_Duchess_of_Norfolk "Elizabeth de Mowbray,
Duchess of Norfolk") that inspired the original illustrations of the Queen of
Hearts.

After unsuccessfully attempting to illustrate _Alice 's Adventures in
Wonderland_ himself, Lewis Carroll was persuaded to engage a professional
artist to provide the illustrations. He turned to cartoonist [John
Tenniel](/wiki/John_Tenniel "John Tenniel"), who was known for his regular
contributions to the satirical magazine _[Punch](/wiki/Punch_\(magazine\)
"Punch \(magazine\)")_ (published 1841–1992, 1996–2002).

Tenniel's inspiration for the Queen of Hearts was an image of [Elizabeth de
Mowbray, Duchess of Norfolk](/wiki/Elizabeth_de_Mowbray,_Duchess_of_Norfolk
"Elizabeth de Mowbray, Duchess of Norfolk") in one of the medieval stained
glass windows at [Holy Trinity Church, Long
Melford](/wiki/Holy_Trinity_Church,_Long_Melford "Holy Trinity Church, Long
Melford"), Suffolk.[1]

The illustrations for the _Alice_ books were engraved onto blocks of wood, to
be printed in the [wood engraving](/wiki/Wood_engraving "Wood engraving")
process. The original wood blocks are now in the collection of the [Bodleian
Library](/wiki/Bodleian_Library "Bodleian Library") in [Oxford](/wiki/Oxford
"Oxford"), England. They are not usually on public display, but were exhibited
in 2003.

## Confusion with the Red
Queen[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Confusion with the Red Queen")]

She is commonly mistaken for the [Red
Queen](/wiki/Red_Queen_\(Through_the_Looking_Glass\) "Red Queen \(Through the
Looking Glass\)") in the story's sequel, _[Through the Looking-
Glass](/wiki/Through_the_Looking-Glass "Through the Looking-Glass")_ , but in
reality shares none of her characteristics other than being a queen. Indeed,
Carroll, in his lifetime, made the distinction of the two Queens by saying:

“ | 

    I pictured to myself the Queen of Hearts as a sort of embodiment of ungovernable [passion](/wiki/Passion_\(emotion\) "Passion \(emotion\)") – a blind and aimless [Fury](/wiki/Erinyes "Erinyes").
    The Red Queen I pictured as a Fury, but of another type; her passion must be cold and calm – she must be formal and strict, yet not unkindly; pedantic to the 10th degree, the concentrated essence of all [governesses](/wiki/Governess "Governess")![2]
| ”  
---|---|---  
— [Lewis Carroll](/wiki/Lewis_Carroll "Lewis Carroll"), in "Alice on the
Stage"  
  
The 1951 animated film _[Alice in
Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(Disney\) "Alice in Wonderland
\(Disney\)")_ perpetuates the long-standing confusion between the Red Queen
and the [Queen of Hearts](/wiki/Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice_character\) "Queen of
Hearts \(Alice character\)"). In the film, the Queen of Hearts delivers
several of the Red Queen's statements, the most notable being based on her
"all the ways about here belong to me". Both characters say this to suggest
importance and possible arrogance, but in the Red Queen's case it has a double
meaning since her status as a Chess-queen means that she can move in any
direction she desires.

In the _[American McGee's Alice](/wiki/American_McGee%27s_Alice "American
McGee's Alice")_ adaptation of the books, the characters are also conflated,
leading to further popular misconception.

##
Adaptions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Adaptions")]

###
Disney[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Disney")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1c/DisneyQueenHearts.jpg/200px-
DisneyQueenHearts.jpg)](/wiki/File:DisneyQueenHearts.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DisneyQueenHearts.jpg "Enlarge")

Disney's adaptation of the Queen of Hearts.

In the Disney animated feature _[Alice in
Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(1951_film\) "Alice in Wonderland
\(1951 film\)")_ , the Queen of Hearts is the main antagonist who appears as
Alice puts it in a moment of temper, a "fat, pompous, bad tempered old
tyrant". The character was voiced by [Verna Felton](/wiki/Verna_Felton "Verna
Felton"). She is portrayed as a [haughty](/wiki/Haughty "Haughty")
[sadist](/wiki/Sadistic_personality_disorder "Sadistic personality disorder"),
who enjoys [decapitating](/wiki/Decapitating "Decapitating") anyone who merely
annoys her. Her presence is all the more striking because of how tiny her
husband the King is (he barely comes up to her knee). Similar to the book,
Alice meets three cards painting the roses red, since they planted white roses
by mistake. When the Queen arrives, she orders those three cards beheaded,
then turns her attention to Alice. Refusing to answer her questions with
presumption that only she can ask them, she quickly ropes her into a game of
[croquet](/wiki/Croquet "Croquet"). The game ends with the Queen tripping
herself over, due to the [Cheshire Cat](/wiki/Cheshire_Cat "Cheshire Cat")'s
mischievous antics. The Queen angrily blames Alice for it, but before she can
give the order, the King suggests holding a trial for Alice. The Queen,
grudgingly, but reasonably, agrees. The Queen calls the [March
Hare](/wiki/March_Hare "March Hare"), the
[Dormouse](/wiki/Dormouse_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\) "Dormouse
\(Alice's Adventures in Wonderland\)"), and the [Mad Hatter](/wiki/Mad_Hatter
"Mad Hatter") to witness, who hold an unbirthday party for her and cheer her
up considerably. During the party, the Cheshire Cat reappears and upsets the
Dormouse. The frightened Dormouse runs all over, and in an attempt to crush
the mouse, the King of Hearts accidentally hits the Queen on the head with the
[gavel](/wiki/Gavel "Gavel"), which is hastily passed into the March Hare's
hands, then the Hatter's, and finally Alice's. The Queen, of course, blames
Alice for it, and is going to have her beheaded. But Alice eats mushrooms she
had procured earlier, which make her grow bigger. Although Rule No. 42 says
that anyone more than a mile high must leave the court immediately, Alice
feels free to call the queen a "fat, pompous, bad tempered old tyrant".
Unfortunately, she subsequently shrinks down to her normal size, but flees and
is able to escape.

Of interest is the fact that Disney's Queen of Hearts seems to be an
[amalgamation](/wiki/Amalgamation_\(fiction\) "Amalgamation \(fiction\)") of
the Queen from the book, the Duchess, and the Red Queen of _[Through The
Looking-Glass](/wiki/Through_The_Looking-Glass "Through The Looking-Glass")_.
When pleased, she can be quite pleasant, but is still bossy and often
impatient, and can almost at once change to enraged.

As she is considered to be one of the members of the [Disney
Villains](/wiki/Disney_Villains "Disney Villains") group of characters, the
Queen of Hearts exacted her revenge upon Alice in the game _[Disney's
Villains' Revenge](/wiki/Disney%27s_Villains%27_Revenge "Disney's Villains'
Revenge")_ where she stole the ending page of the story and changed the
ending, so Alice lost her head. [Jiminy Cricket](/wiki/Jiminy_Cricket "Jiminy
Cricket"), the player, and Alice's headless body retrieve the head and escape
the labyrinth of the Queen. They meet one last time in the final battle and
she surrenders. The Queen of Hearts is the [final
boss](/wiki/Boss_\(video_gaming\) "Boss \(video gaming\)") on the Japanese
version of _[Mickey Mousecapade](/wiki/Mickey_Mousecapade "Mickey
Mousecapade")_ , a 1987 video game where Alice is her hostage. She is also a
greetable character at the [Walt Disney World
Resort](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World_Resort "Walt Disney World Resort"). In
_[Mickey's House of Villains](/wiki/Mickey%27s_House_of_Villains "Mickey's
House of Villains")_, the Queen of Hearts appears as one of the villain guests
of the _House of Mouse_ , voiced by [Tress MacNeille](/wiki/Tress_MacNeille
"Tress MacNeille").

The Queen appears in the [Square-Enix](/wiki/Square-Enix "Square-
Enix")/[Disney](/wiki/Disney "Disney") video game _[Kingdom
Hearts](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts "Kingdom Hearts")_ , in her homeworld. As in the
film, she holds Alice on trial, only this time for attempting to steal her
heart. The main heroes in the game, Sora, Donald and Goofy, intervene, telling
the Queen that Alice is innocent. The Queen challenges them to provide proof
of their theory, and with help from the Cheshire Cat, the three are able to do
so. The Queen, however, enraged at being proven wrong, orders them executed
and Alice imprisoned in a cage on the roof. The three are able to fight off
the Queen's guards and destroy the cage controls, but Alice is kidnapped,
before they can save her. The Queen orders a search for Alice, and temporarily
pardons Sora, Donald and Goofy, requesting that they look for Alice as well.
She returns in _[Kingdom Hearts: Chain of
Memories](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts:_Chain_of_Memories "Kingdom Hearts: Chain of
Memories")_ , only this time as a figment of Sora's memories. Again, she holds
Alice on trial, this time for attempting to steal her memories. In both games,
Sora, Donald and Goofy prove Alice's innocence by defeating the Trickmaster
Heartless, the real culprit. The Queen congratulates Sora for solving the
mystery, and once again demonstrates her bi-polar personality by pardoning
Alice. She is absent in _[Kingdom Hearts II](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_II "Kingdom
Hearts II")_ , but appears in _[Kingdom Hearts 358/2
Days](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_358/2_Days "Kingdom Hearts 358/2 Days")_ along with
her homeworld. A digital version of her later appears in _[Kingdom Hearts
coded](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_coded "Kingdom Hearts coded")_.

### Tim Burton's _Alice in Wonderland_
(2010)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland \(2010\)")]

Main article: [Red Queen (Through the Looking-Glass) § Tim Burton's Alice in
Wonderland (2010)](/wiki/Red_Queen_\(Through_the_Looking-
Glass\)#Tim_Burton.27s_Alice_in_Wonderland_.282010.29 "Red Queen \(Through the
Looking-Glass\)")

### _American McGee 's
Alice_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: American McGee's Alice")]

In the video game _[American McGee's Alice](/wiki/American_McGee%27s_Alice
"American McGee's Alice")_, the Queen of Hearts is the final boss and the
reason for Wonderland's decay. When Alice fights her, she discovers that the
Queen is her dark side – an embodiment of her insanity; the Queen must be
destroyed for Alice to become sane once more. The Queen's appearance is
different in _American McGee 's Alice_ from how she is in the book: she
appears first as a faceless entity having tentacles for arms, legs, and hair.
It is later revealed that this is a mere puppet and that the true Queen of
Hearts is a horrible monster in the image of a real anatomical heart. She is
called both the Queen of Hearts and the Red Queen interchangeably throughout
the game. No mention is made of the Red Queen from "Through the Looking
Glass." However, the White Queen is seen for only a moment, as her head is
chopped off by the enemy in The Pale Realm. It's implied that after Alice was
placed in the asylum the red queen and the queen of hearts fused together
which explains why the Queen of Hearts is able to control the red piece and
the cards at the same time.

In the sequel, _[Alice: Madness Returns](/wiki/Alice:_Madness_Returns "Alice:
Madness Returns")_ , the Queen of Hearts is sought by Alice for assistance in
stopping an Infernal Train from tearing apart Wonderland and driving her back
into insanity. The Queen claims, when found in the ruins of the Red Kingdom,
that Alice is being manipulated by someone other than herself, that this
person is trying to erase her memories, particularly about the fire in her
childhood, which are tearing her sanity apart. It later turns out that this
person is none other than her psychiatrist Dr. Angus Bumby, who has been
revealed to having raped Alice's older sister Lizzy and burned down the house
with Lizzy and Alice's parents to cover up the crime, and that he is
attempting to erase Alice's memories and subject her to prostitution after it.
In this sequel, the Red Queen has changed considerably, taking the appearance
of a younger Alice, only in a royal dress befitting the Queen of Hearts, with
large fleshy claws rather than hands, and her lower body composed of fleshy
tentacles that spread throughout the entire castle, which is actually the
Queen's body itself. Some argue she is actually based not on Alice herself,
but her sister, as she also referred to her as "Lizzy" in a following
dialogue, and considering she felt guilty of the death of her family, its
possible her subconscious projected her dead sister in the queen she herself
killed in the previous game.

### The Looking-Glass
Wars[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: The Looking-Glass Wars")]

In _[The Looking Glass Wars](/wiki/The_Looking_Glass_Wars "The Looking Glass
Wars")_ by Frank Beddor, the ruling dynasty of the Wonderland is the Heart
family. The title of Queen of Hearts is a hereditary title for the Queen of
Wonderland. The Queen of Hearts from Alice in Wonderland is reimagined as
[Queen Redd](/wiki/Queen_Redd "Queen Redd"), the enemy and aunt of the
heroine, Alyss. She kills Alyss's parents and [usurps](/wiki/Usurper
"Usurper") the throne of Wonderland.

It should be noted that the true Queen of Hearts in this story is Genevieve
Heart, Alyss's mother as an apparent re-imagining of the [White
Queen](/wiki/White_Queen_\(Through_the_Looking_Glass\) "White Queen \(Through
the Looking Glass\)"). Alyss is, therefore, the Princess of Hearts.

### Alice in the Country of
Hearts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Alice in the Country of Hearts")]

In the manga [Alice in the Country of
Hearts](/wiki/Alice_in_the_Country_of_Hearts "Alice in the Country of
Hearts"), the Queen of Hearts is known as Vivaldi. She isn't as much a main
character, though, and she has very few parts in the current books. Vivaldi
rules Heart Castle and is feuding with the other territories over
[Wonderland](/wiki/Wonderland_\(fictional_country\) "Wonderland \(fictional
country\)"). She is beautiful with black hair, unlike other adaptations. She
speaks in the [majestic plural](/wiki/Majestic_plural "Majestic plural"), I.E,
"We are happy you are here to see us." As discovered through Heart no Kuni no
Alice the game by Quinrose (the predecessor to the manga) Blood Dupree (The
Hatter) is Vivaldi's little brother though it is alluded to be a romantic
interest for Vivaldi until Alice discovers the secret.

### SyFy TV
miniseries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: SyFy TV miniseries")]

In the two-part series _[Alice](/wiki/Alice_\(TV_miniseries\) "Alice \(TV
miniseries\)")_ , hosted by the SyFy Channel, the Queen of Hearts is portrayed
by [Kathy Bates](/wiki/Kathy_Bates "Kathy Bates") as a refined but ruthless
drug lord. The miniseries is set one hundred and fifty years after the
original Alice's first visit to Wonderland (the heroine is an unrelated
character) and the Queen is (as usual) the primary villain of the series. As
is customary, the Queen is depicted as [narcissistic](/wiki/Narcissistic
"Narcissistic"), declaring herself as "the most powerful woman in the history
of literature" and [obese](/wiki/Obese "Obese"). Her calm, cold demeanour
suggests that she too is a mixture of the Queen of Hearts and the Red Queen.
Her name is given as "Mary Elizabeth Heart", and it is suggested that the
Hearts are the "Red" royal family who seized control of Wonderland from the
"White" royal family.

### Once Upon a
Time[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Once Upon a Time")]

  * The Queen of Hearts appears in the _[Once Upon a Time](/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Time_\(TV_series\) "Once Upon a Time \(TV series\)")_ episode ."[Hat Trick](/wiki/Hat_Trick_\(Once_Upon_a_Time\) "Hat Trick \(Once Upon a Time\)")", played by Jennifer Koenig. In the show's second season, it is revealed that the Queen of Hearts is in fact Cora ([Barbara Hershey](/wiki/Barbara_Hershey "Barbara Hershey")), the mother of the [Wicked Witch of the West](/wiki/Wicked_Witch_of_the_West "Wicked Witch of the West") and the [Evil Queen](/wiki/Queen_\(Snow_White\) "Queen \(Snow White\)"). In her earlier life, Cora (portrayed by [Rose McGowan](/wiki/Rose_McGowan "Rose McGowan")) was also the miller's daughter (the heroine of the _[Rumpelstiltskin](/wiki/Rumpelstiltskin "Rumpelstiltskin")_ story). She appears in every season throughout the show most often portrayed by [Barbara Hershey](/wiki/Barbara_Hershey "Barbara Hershey") but at younger age portrayed by [Rose McGowan](/wiki/Rose_McGowan "Rose McGowan"). She was the main antagonist of Season 2.
  * In the show's spin-off, _[Once Upon a Time in Wonderland](/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Time_in_Wonderland "Once Upon a Time in Wonderland")_ , a flashback reveals that Cora (as the Queen of Hearts) was the [Red Queen's](/wiki/Red_Queen_\(Through_the_Looking-Glass\)#Once_Upon_a_Time_in_Wonderland "Red Queen \(Through the Looking-Glass\)") tutor in magic; Cora apparently ruled part of Wonderland and was a political rival of the Red King.

### Other versions and
adaptations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Other versions and adaptations")]

  * In various film and television versions of the novel,[3] The Queen has been played by [May Robson](/wiki/May_Robson "May Robson"), [Ronald Lang](/w/index.php?title=Ronald_Lang&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ronald Lang \(page does not exist\)"), [Zsa Zsa Gabor](/wiki/Zsa_Zsa_Gabor "Zsa Zsa Gabor"), [Eve Arden](/wiki/Eve_Arden "Eve Arden"), [Jayne Meadows](/wiki/Jayne_Meadows "Jayne Meadows"), and, In the 1999 _[Alice in Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(1999_film\) "Alice in Wonderland \(1999 film\)")_ television movie, [Miranda Richardson](/wiki/Miranda_Richardson "Miranda Richardson"), whose portrayal is strongly reminiscent of her role as the spoiled [Queenie](/wiki/Queenie_\(Blackadder\) "Queenie \(Blackadder\)") in _[Blackadder](/wiki/Blackadder "Blackadder")_.
  * In an episode of _[Wizards of Waverly Place](/wiki/Wizards_of_Waverly_Place "Wizards of Waverly Place")_ parodying the novel, Alex Russo is in court and becomes smart with the Queen of Hearts (played by Theresa Russo).
  * In the 1991 Disney channel series _[Adventures in Wonderland](/wiki/Adventures_in_Wonderland "Adventures in Wonderland")_ , the Queen was played by [Armelia McQueen](/wiki/Armelia_McQueen "Armelia McQueen"). She appears as a short-tempered and childish but basically benevolent ruler. She was alternately called "The Queen of Hearts" and "The Red Queen" during the course of the series.
  * In [Sandra the Fairytale Detective](/wiki/Sandra_the_Fairytale_Detective "Sandra the Fairytale Detective"), her name is Theressa.
  * [Pandora Hearts](/wiki/Pandora_Hearts "Pandora Hearts") has Miranda Barma who would later become the chain Demios the Executor also nicknamed Queen of Hearts and they have a similar obsession of cutting heads.
  * The Queen is one of the characters adopted by [Gwen Stefani](/wiki/Gwen_Stefani "Gwen Stefani") in her [Wonderland](/wiki/Wonderland_\(fictional_country\) "Wonderland \(fictional country\)")-themed music video [What You Waiting For?](/wiki/What_You_Waiting_For%3F "What You Waiting For?"). She wears a red gown and a crown reminiscent of the [Imperial State Crown](/wiki/Imperial_State_Crown "Imperial State Crown") from the [British Crown Jewels](/wiki/British_Crown_Jewels "British Crown Jewels"). The Queen wanders through a garden populated with [flamingos](/wiki/Flamingo "Flamingo") and pushes Alice (also Stefani) into a pool of her own tears.
  * The Queen of Hearts features in [Unsuk Chin](/wiki/Unsuk_Chin "Unsuk Chin")'s 2007 opera _[Alice in Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(opera\) "Alice in Wonderland \(opera\)")_ ; the role was created for [Dame Gwyneth Jones](/wiki/Gwyneth_Jones_\(soprano\) "Gwyneth Jones \(soprano\)").
  * The Queen is a major character in [Christopher Wheeldon](/wiki/Christopher_Wheeldon "Christopher Wheeldon")'s 2011 full-length ballet _[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland](/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland_\(ballet\) "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland \(ballet\)")_, created for [The Royal Ballet](/wiki/The_Royal_Ballet "The Royal Ballet"). The role was created for principal dancer [Zenaida Yanowsky](/wiki/Zenaida_Yanowsky "Zenaida Yanowsky")[4] and includes a hilarious spoof of the Rose Adagio from _[The Sleeping Beauty](/wiki/The_Sleeping_Beauty_\(ballet\) "The Sleeping Beauty \(ballet\)")_.
  * The Queen appeared briefly during the [2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony "2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony") in London in a segment dedicated to the villains of British children's literature.
  * In [Marissa Meyer](/wiki/Marissa_Meyer "Marissa Meyer")'s 2016 novel _Heartless_ , the backstory of the Queen of Hearts is told, in which she is a young girl who aspires to be a baker, but is instead taken off course by the anticipated proposal of the King of Hearts.[5]
  * The Queen of Hearts appears in the twelfth episode ("And the Broken Staff") of _[The Librarians](/wiki/The_Librarians_\(2014_TV_series\) "The Librarians \(2014 TV series\)")_. She is brought to life by the wizard [Prospero](/wiki/Prospero "Prospero") as a distraction for the Librarians, but is subsequently tricked into attacking her own reflection, turning her into a pack of cards (mirroring the ending of the original story).
